oai_dc:dc.dc:title: FINITE-ELEMENT STUDY ON THE ROLE OF CONVECTION IN LASER-SURFACE MELTING
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: RAVINDRAN, K
SRINIVASAN, J
MARATHE, AG
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: navier-stokes equations
flow
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The surface-tension-driven convection in laser melting has been simulated by the Galerkin finite element method. The governing laminar, axisymmetric convection equations are solved in a sequential manner by an explicit projection method. The numerical results show a strong dependence of the flow pattern on the value of the temperature coefficient of surface tension (sigma(T)). Results are presented for a range of sigma(T) values typical in steel, -10(-4) less-than-or-equal-to sigma(T) less-than-or-equal-to + 10(-4) N / mK. As the melt depth is more affected than the width, the melt aspect ratio changes due to convection. The melt pool is broad and shallow when sigma(T) < 0, and deep and narrow when sigma(T) > 0.
